sources.title: Articles on Smashing Magazine — For Web Designers And Developers

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Ceara Crawshaw)
articles.description: When bad UX has lingered in a product for so long, it can feel like a mountain to overcome. In this article, Ceara Crawshaw shares her advice on how you can invoke joy and assure the quality in the work done on product teams.
articles.title: Preventing Bad UX Through Integrated Design Workflows

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Jhey Tompkins)
articles.description: In this article, Jhey Tompkins explores one of GreenSocks’ newest plugins alongside React to create an impractical whimsical spin on a well-known native element: ``.
articles.title: What If Our Sliders Actually Slid?

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Georgy Marchuk)
articles.description: Have you ever wondered, why do people write CLI tools? When is a good time to think about yours? Today we’ll touch on these questions, along with some tips to remember when creating one. However, all of this serves as a prelude to the real topic: end-to-end testing of CLI tools.
articles.title: Testing The CLI The Way People Use It

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Vitaly Friedman)
articles.description: In UX, we can use navigation queries, evaluation journeys, A-Z index and tap-ahead autocomplete to help users get where they want to be, faster. Let’s find out how.
articles.title: Designing Better Navigation With Navigation Queries

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: Who doesn’t love a good timesaver? In this post, we compiled useful productivity tips and tools that help you speed up routine tasks, enhance your development workflow, and stay organized.
articles.title: Productivity Tips And Tools For A More Efficient Workflow

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Ekene Eze)
articles.description: In this article, Ekene Eze shares his thoughts about the direction of the web in 2022, and what solutions we can expect to see come up in the ecosystem to significantly improve the Jamstack experience.
articles.title: Jamstack Rendering Patterns: The Evolution

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Lee Munroe)
articles.description: What are the benefits of using push notifications and what can you use them for? In this article, Lee Munroe explains how to implement them and which practices are best to follow.
articles.title: The Ultimate Guide To Push Notifications For Developers

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Marli Mesibov)
articles.description: Storytelling is a powerful tool for any UX designer. It helps create a product and understand the people who use it. In this article, Marli Mesibov takes a real-life example of an app she helped to build in 2017 and explains five steps you can use to help you build a story into your user experience.
articles.title: How To Use Storytelling In UX

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Paul Boag)
articles.description: Whether you work in-house or run a digital agency, there are occasions when you will consider hiring freelancers to supplement your team. Today, we’ll take a look into a platform known as [Upwork](https://upwork.pxf.io/c/1221738/1245573/13634) and the best ways in finding the the right freelancers as well as integrating them into your team.
articles.title: When And How To Use Freelancers In Your Organization

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Vitaly Friedman)
articles.description: Carousels don’t have a good reputation, and rightfully so. But we can make them more useful. **Best practices and guidelines** to improve the carousel design with honest scrolling direction, labels, thumbnails and grouped prev/next-buttons.
articles.title: Designing A Better Carousel UX

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Dan Donald)
articles.description: Like many things, a design system isn’t ever a finished thing — it’s a journey. How we go about that journey can affect the things we produce along the way. Before diving in and starting to plan anything out, be clear about where the benefits and the risks might lie.
articles.title: Around The Artifacts Of Design Systems (Case Study)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Adrian Bece)
articles.description: This new attribute will enable us to fine-tune relative resource priority, improve LCP performance, deprioritize JavaScript fetch calls, and much more. Let’s check out fetchpriority and explore some potential use cases.
articles.title: Boost Resource Loading With fetchpriority, A New Priority Hint

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Caleb Olojo)
articles.description: Data is among the most important things that make up a web application or a conventional native app. We need data to be able to see and perhaps understand the purpose of an application. In this article, we’ll look at another approach to obtaining data in an application that requires authentication or authorization using Next.js.
articles.title: Dynamic Data-Fetching In An Authenticated Next.js App

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Vitaly Friedman)
articles.description: In this series of articles, we highlight design patterns and techniques to design better interfaces. You can also find more examples in [“Smart Interface Design Patterns”](https://smart-interface-design-patterns.com/), a 6h-video course with 100s of hand-picked examples, curated by Vitaly.
articles.title: Designing Better Breadcrumbs

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: [Devs For Ukraine](https://www.devsforukraine.io/) is a free online charity conference organized by the lovely people at Remote. Two days filled with talks from engineering leaders around the globe, in support of Ukraine. April 25–26.
articles.title: Devs For Ukraine, A Free Online Charity Conference 🇺🇦

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Paul Boag)
articles.description: Whether you work in-house or for an external agency, we all share one challenge — dealing with stakeholders, be they your boss, colleagues, or clients. In this post, veteran web designer Paul Boag shares his approach to getting things done in even the most challenging organizations.
articles.title: How To Get Work Done: Wrangling Stakeholders And Overcoming Obstacles

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Manuel Matuzović)
articles.description: Ever wondered how to build a paginated list that works with and without JavaScript? In this article, Manuel explains how you can leverage the power of Progressive Enhancement and do just that with Eleventy and Alpine.js.
articles.title: How To Build A Progressively Enhanced, Accessible, Filterable And Paginated List

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Sam Poder)
articles.description: Next.js’ recent 12.0 release included a new beta feature: middleware. For a detailed explanation, you can read all about it in Sam’s previous article, “[Next.js Wildcard Subdomains](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2021/11/nextjs-wildcard-subdomains/)”. This article, on the other hand, dives into the overall concept of middleware and how handy it can be in building things.
articles.title: The What, When, Why And How Of Next.js’ New Middleware Feature

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: Let’s welcome the new month with some new wallpapers. Designed with love by artists and designers from across the globe, they are available in versions with and without a calendar for April 2022.
articles.title: A Time For Reflection (April 2022 Desktop Wallpapers Edition)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Vitaly Friedman)
articles.description: Best practices and guidelines to improve the UX of infinite scroll with bookmarks, footer reveal and pagination.
articles.title: Designing A Better Infinite Scroll

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Jarijn Nijkamp)
articles.description: After two years when almost everything moved online, 2022 marks the return of in-person conferences. In fact, [SmashingConf is back](https://smashingconf.com/conferences): coming to  San Francisco and Austin in June, Freiburg (Germany) in September, and New York in October.
articles.title: SmashingConf Is Back In 2022

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: Are you a designer or developer affected by the war in Ukraine? Here are some options to consider if you’re looking for a design or tech job.
articles.title: Jobs For Designers And Developers Affected By The War In Ukraine 🇺🇦

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cristian Díaz)
articles.description: In this article, we’ll talk about how to adapt our sites to the different scenarios of a device pointer: whether it has a pointer or not, or how accurate it is. To adapt our site to those devices’ needs we’ll talk about how to properly use media queries `hover`, `pointer`, `any-hover` and `any-pointer`.
articles.title: A Guide To Hover And Pointer Media Queries

articles.author: Ijelekhai Faith Olohijere
articles.description: In this article, we'll learn a few different ways to resize elements and groups in Figma (in addition to the default method). We'll also learn how to resize frames without moving elements in the frames. In Figma, there are other ways to resize elements apart from the default method. So
articles.title: How to Resize Elements in Figma

articles.author: Aris Zagakos
articles.description: In this article we will discuss Homomorphic Encryption, the problem that it solves, and the different types that exist.  Then we will write code in Python to show some of its capabilities in action. Here's what we'll cover:  1. What is Homomorphic Encryption?  2. Advantages of Homomorphic
articles.title: What is Homomorphic Encryption?

articles.author: Popoola Temitope
articles.description: Vite.js [/news/p/e534a679-ce3c-4cf1-842b-96087d30944d/Vite.js] is a rapid development tool for modern web projects. It focuses on speed and performance by improving the development experience. Vite uses native browser ES imports to enable support for modern browsers without a build process. Vite consists of two major parts:  * The dev server provides
articles.title: Vite.js Tutorial – How to Install and Use Vite in Your Web Projects

articles.author: Germán Cocca
articles.description: Hi everyone! In this article we will talk about memoization, an optimization technique that can help make heavy computation processes more efficient. We will start by talking about what memoization is and when it's best to implement it. Later on we will give practical examples for JavaScript and React. Table
articles.title: What is Memoization? How and When to Memoize in JavaScript and React

articles.author: Ihechikara Vincent Abba
articles.description: The SOLID design principles help us create maintainable, reusable, and flexible software designs. Each letter in the acronym SOLID stands for a specific principle.  Here is what each letter in the acronym stands for:  * S: Single responsibility principle.  * O: Open–closed principle.  * L: Liskov
articles.title: SOLID Definition – the SOLID Principles of Object-Oriented Design Explained

articles.author: Dionysia Lemonaki
articles.description: Sometimes you might want to delay the execution of your code. You may need certain lines of code to execute at a point in the future, when you explicitly specify, rather than all the code executing synchronously. Something like that is possible with JavaScript. In this article, you will learn
